lead_paragraph: SILVERMAN--Robert E.,professor and consummate fly fisherman, died at the age of 91 in his home in Naples, Florida on January 3, 2016. He was born in Providence, RI on March 1, 1924 to Natalie (nee Jess) and Samuel Silverman. After attending Brown University for one year (class of '46), he enlisted in the Army where he served abroad for three years during WWII. Upon returning he re-enrolled in Brown University and graduated in 1949. He received his PhD in psychology from Indiana University in 1952 and accepted a job at New York University, where he spent his entire professional career (moving from the University Heights Campus to the Washington Square Campus in 1973) until retiring in 1983. During his tenure there, he served as Assistant Dean of the College of Arts and Sciences (1959-1962) and department chair (1961-1970). He also wrote a successful introductory psychology textbook. He spent the next 35 years fishing, studying the Daily Racing Form, betting on race horses, and writing. During this period he moved from homes in Great Neck, Montauk, San Diego, CA and Marathon Key, eventually settling in Naples, Florida. He is predeceased by his wife of 63 years, Margaret Takacs Silverman. He is survived by his brother, Perry Silverman, two daughters, Pamela Silverman and Jill Silverman, and four grandchildren. At his request, his ashes are to be scattered on his favorite lake in Maine, where he fished for trout and salmon yearly for over 50 years. 1/3
